title: Want to Shape Culture? Stop Jumping on Trends
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-24, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flbbonline.com%2Fnews%2FWant-to-Shape-Culture-Stop-Jumping-on-Trends%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/0100019a15e59af9-866a645c-ee17-4e1f-bf55-14a9f5aa165a-000000/75MtYtRjiXi6fZIgX3dpAT4XiZSpd4BtLaG_KRzgJos=428
summary: Want to Shape Culture? Stop Jumping on Trends (4 minute read) Brands seeking cultural influence should stop chasing trends and focus on setting them. Trend-jumping may bring short-term visibility, but audiences, especially Gen Z, recognize inauthentic content and quickly lose interest. Impact comes from a clear brand voice, purpose, and perspective used to lead conversations. Thoughtful, original social activations help brands stand out in a crowded digital landscape.

title: Brands Are Paying More For Ads That Do Less

summary: Brands Are Paying More For Ads That Do Less (2 minute read) Ad budgets are rising faster than results. Shutterstock's 2025 Creative Impact Report shows a 33% jump in marketing spend but only a 17% lift in purchase intent since 2023. The widening 20% impact gap signals a broken model, especially for brands leaning on high-volume output. Today's environment demands carefully curated and culturally aware creatives.

title: Hacking Formula 1: Accessing Max Verstappen's passport and PII through FIA bugs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-24, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fian.sh%2Ffia%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/0100019a15e9a9a3-bd3e7151-a193-418e-9858-13fa3953167c-000000/mP3fjXfQCZ7-Uq-m_9zTwZ6cK-deScoCwwyoI5gFwQQ=428
summary: Hacking Formula 1: Accessing Max Verstappen's passport and PII through FIA bugs (5 minute read) Devs discovered a vulnerability in the FIA Driver Categorisation portal that allowed them to escalate their privileges to administrator. This admin access granted them the ability to view sensitive PII, including passports and resumes, of F1 drivers like Max Verstappen. The vulnerability was reported to the FIA, which took the site offline and implemented a fix.

title: 4 Unconventional Ways to Cast in Typescript
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-24, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwolfgirl.dev%2Fblog%2F2025-10-22-4-unconventional-ways-to-cast-in-typescript%2F%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/0100019a15e9a9a3-bd3e7151-a193-418e-9858-13fa3953167c-000000/0d3q_l_lArzPnIairGr1rG0eI8QHfcZxa5U2jEl2hoQ=428
summary: 4 Unconventional Ways to Cast in Typescript (8 minute read) This article goes over four unconventional methods to cast between types in TypeScript, showing potential unsoundness in the language's type system. These methods include abusing the `is` operator, using mutation across boundaries, exploiting structural typing, and manipulating `void` type combinations. While TypeScript generally provides good type safety, these techniques can introduce subtle bugs and unsafety.

title: How Memory Maps Deliver 25x Faster File Access in Go
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-24, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Finfo.varnish-software.com%2Fblog%2Fhow-memory-maps-mmap-deliver-25x-faster-file-access-in-go%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/0100019a15e9a9a3-bd3e7151-a193-418e-9858-13fa3953167c-000000/1IZQVIrHNWKNfyjvOGJzTC8EKDeD6QWemCzfrP81ePs=428
summary: How Memory Maps (mmap) Deliver 25x Faster File Access in Go (5 minute read) Memory maps in Unix allow a file to be mapped into virtual memory, enabling direct reads via pointers instead of slower seek/read operations. Benchmarks in Go show memory maps can be up to 25 times faster than using `ReaderAt` for random lookups and iterations. While writing to memory maps is inefficient due to page faults, they can still be great for read-heavy operations when files are cached.

title: The price of mandatory code reviews
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-24, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fopen.substack.com%2Fpub%2Fzaidesanton%2Fp%2Fthe-price-of-mandatory-code-reviews%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/0100019a15e9a9a3-bd3e7151-a193-418e-9858-13fa3953167c-000000/aO7CkUQOatC09RF9gMbX_eMTCPXMSd4YrRru3-xgSD0=428
summary: The price of mandatory code reviews (7 minute read) Based on data from 400+ companies and 3,000+ engineers, this article challenges the mandatory code review practice in software development. The research found that teams without code reviews are 1.9x more productive but produce 2.4x more bugs, while high-quality reviews (though 38% slower) reduce bugs by 61% compared to low-quality ones. Top-performing teams (90th percentile) achieve both speed and quality by being selective about when revie...

title: What Happened to Apple's Legendary Attention to Detail?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-24, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.johnozbay.com%2Fwhat-happened-to-apples-attention-to-detail.html%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/0100019a15e9a9a3-bd3e7151-a193-418e-9858-13fa3953167c-000000/81u75pATsANkOLsP_44Ry16LZ3AVz83UxzD6fVe3smY=428
summary: What Happened to Apple's Legendary Attention to Detail? (11 minute read) Apple's attention to detail, a hallmark of the brand, has declined in the last 8-10 years. This article points out inconsistent UI design across apps, intrusive permission requests, and the buggy, visually flawed "liquid glass" design as evidence of a decline in user experience.
